NC Public Schools
June 23 at 4:05 PM ·

The application period is open for the State Board of Education (SBE) Student Advisors and the Superintendent's Student Advisory Council. If you are interested in education policy, learning about the education system at the state level and being a voice for your fellow classmates, then these advisory roles may be a good fit for you!

The two-year positions are open to rising high school juniors who will serve through their senior year. The SBE Advisors meet two days per month, aligned with the SBE's monthly meetings. The Superintendent's Advisors will meet one day per month. To apply, visit https://forms.gle/85qZXLtCJUF2snQx5. Application deadline is July 15.

post_text: Senior Shout-out for the last day of April goes to Emily Iannuzzi. Emily is a National Merit Scholar, a member of the OPS High Flyers Club, Beta Club, Interact Club, Equestrian Club and served as Chief Marshal. Her talents extend far beyond academic ones. She is a master baker and delighted her classmates when she presented her senior project - one they could EAT. Emily is an accomplished horsewoman and has received state and national recognition. She uses her love of horses to serve others by working with younger children. Emily is also a member of the Cross Country team. Her artistic talents have also merited recognition including 1st place in 2019 with 4H of North Carolina. Although Emily gained acceptances at UPenn, University of Oklahoma and NC State, she has chosen to accept a full scholarship to the College of Engineering at the University of Alabama. Teacher SHOUT-OUT to lead us into Spring Break goes to Art Teacher Karen Orlando-Clayton. Not only does Karen bring the beauty of art to OPS and her students every day, she also brings what seems to be limitless energy and insight to young leaders as the advisor to Interact. Karen is one of the people that students rely upon to hear them, guide them and provide them with gentle, wise counsel. Whether or not they have had a class with her, many students see Mrs. Clayton as their 2nd mom and you can often find them in her classroom just because they "needed to talk to her." Teachers also see Karen as someone they can turn to with questions or for an understanding ear and good advice.

Karen enjoys living "out in the country" with her husband Clint and her mom just across the road. She has 2 grown daughters. In June 2019 Karen took on a new role - that of Mother-in-law and now in just a few weeks Karen will have yet another new title - that of Grandmother. Congratulations to today's Teacher Shout-Out, Karen Clayton. RISE, Griffins, RISE!

DID YOU KNOW that Granville County offers a Summer Civic Leadership Program for high school students? This program provides opportunities for rising seniors to learn how their local county government operates. Participants are selected through a competitive application and interview process for a five-week rotation through Granville County departments as they gain “hands-on” experience in general government, human services, public safety and community service. Upon program completion, each participating student will receive educational assistance in the form of a scholarship check to help fund their secondary education and/or training of their own choosing. Pictured are last year's participants Anthony Goreman, Brooklyn Pridgen, Tanaura Harrison, Akoya Penny-Campbell and Sarah Elliott. Click here for more information or to apply: https://www.granvillecounty.org/government/administration/summer-civic-leadership-program/.

The OPS Board of Directors held a special called meeting yesterday evening to receive confirmation that the USDA has approved the school’s $10,960,000 loan application to construct a permanent lower school building and a multipurpose athletic field, with an anticipated completion no later than July 2021.

In addition, the OPS Board reviewed several facility options to move forward with K – 4 expansion for the upcoming 2020 – 2021 school year. After review and discussion, the OPS Board approved a motion to pursue the purchase of land adjacent to the current OPS campus and install a temporary modular facility in order to serve grades K-12 on the Landis Rd. campus for the upcoming 2020 – 2021 school year. Enrollment targets for each of the new K – 4 grades have been modified to reflect this new facility plan.

Open enrollment for potential new K – 12 students continues through 2/28/20. In addition, many employment opportunities have been posted to the school’s website whereby qualified applicants are encouraged to apply.

post_text: Senior Fine Arts Projects are being presented. OPS is NOT an arts school. OPS is a college prep school and it is believed that the arts are an integral support not only for success in high level academics but also in living a full future life. Through the fine arts, history is captured. Just like students will be required to do during their college major coursework, students must research specific topics of interest, write a research paper, create a fine arts product that represents the research, and then present to an audience of peers and staff as a graduation requirement for OPS. Students have built memory benches, written and performed music to research its impact on the emotions of listeners, crafted representations of how they see the community of OPS. They have written poetry, created podcasts and videos. Griffins have captured the moment in photographs and in prose. Graduating Griffins have written and performed short plays, completed campus beautification projects, built conductor's stands. RISE Griffins RISE!
